metadata.description: Ritualized festivals in Francophone Belgium (Wallonia) are central to civic pride and historical commemoration. Many saint-military marches, featuring hundreds in Napoleonic-era uniforms escorting a saint statue, received UNESCO recognition in 2012 as 'Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity.' These processions often involve families with generations of participation. Binche is famous for its Carnival, featuring les Gillesmasked men with ostrich plume headdresses. In Mons and Ath, saint processions evolved into large-scale celebrations: Mons' festival includes mock combat with a dragon, while Aths features giant statues. The Carnival of Binche (2003), Le Doudou of Mons (2005), and La Ducasse of Ath (2005) all hold UNESCO recognition. These traditions, dating back to the late medieval period, ceased during the French Revolution but were revived in the 19th century. This talk explores their reinvention, 20th-century evolution, and their role in modern community identity. Bio: Dr. Erik Hadley earned his BA in History from the University of Montana and his MA and PhD from the University at Buffalo, specializing in Early Modern Europe and the Atlantic World. He is a lecturer in the History Department at Boise State University, teaching medieval and early modern Europe and oceanic histories. His research focuses on cultural history, folkloric rituals, identity, and commemoration in Western Europe and indigenous cultures of the Americas and Hawaii. Dr. Hadley received a 2019-2020 Fulbright Research U.S. Scholar grant to Belgium to study the historical evolution and public memory of UNESCO-recognized folkloric festivals. He has authored numerous articles on cultural identity in French-speaking Belgium.
